natural problem: Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$?
natural solution: A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);

draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.

Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);

pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));

markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]

size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);

label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c x y z :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 40"
and h1 : "b = 60"
and h2 : "c = 80"
and h3 : "x + y + z = a + b + c"
shows  "y = 60"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);
 draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
 label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.
 Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);
 pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,B,X,Y,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,C,Z,X,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Y,Z,A,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]
 size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);
 label("$70^\circ$",Z+(0,.1),NW); label("$70^\circ$",Y+(0,-.2),SW); label("$50^\circ$",X+(0,-.3),SW); [/asy]
 Therefore \[\angle YZX=180^\circ-50^\circ - 70^\circ=\boxed{60^\circ}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c x y z :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 40"
and h1 : "b = 60"
and h2 : "c = 80"
and h3 : "x + y + z = a + b + c"
shows  "y = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $a = 40$, $b = 60$, and $c = 80$, if $x + y + z = a + b + c$, find the value of $y$. The final answer is $60$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: real
assumes h0 : "in_circle A B C X Y Z"
and h1 : "X \<in> segment B C \<and> Y \<in> segment A B \<and> Z \<in> segment A C"
and h2 : "A = 40"
and h3 : "B = 60"
and h4 : "C = 80"
shows  "angle Y Z X = 60"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);
 draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
 label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.
 Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);
 pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,B,X,Y,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,C,Z,X,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Y,Z,A,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]
 size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);
 label("$70^\circ$",Z+(0,.1),NW); label("$70^\circ$",Y+(0,-.2),SW); label("$50^\circ$",X+(0,-.3),SW); [/asy]
 Therefore \[\angle YZX=180^\circ-50^\circ - 70^\circ=\boxed{60^\circ}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: real
assumes h0 : "in_circle A B C X Y Z"
and h1 : "X \<in> segment B C \<and> Y \<in> segment A B \<and> Z \<in> segment A C"
and h2 : "A = 40"
and h3 : "B = 60"
and h4 : "C = 80"
shows  "angle Y Z X = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a triangle with angles A, B, and C, a point X lies on side BC, a point Y lies on side AB, and a point Z lies on side AC such that the points X, Y, and Z form a circle. Given that angle A is 40 degrees, angle B is 60 degrees, and angle C is 80 degrees, find the measure of angle YZX. The final answer is 60 degrees.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes angleA angleB angleC angleYZX :: real
assumes h0 : "angleA = 40"
and h1 : "angleB = 60"
and h2 : "angleC = 80"
and h3 : "angleA + angleB + angleC = 180"
and h4 : "angleYZX = angleB"
shows  "angleYZX = 60"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);
 draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
 label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.
 Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);
 pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,B,X,Y,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,C,Z,X,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Y,Z,A,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]
 size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);
 label("$70^\circ$",Z+(0,.1),NW); label("$70^\circ$",Y+(0,-.2),SW); label("$50^\circ$",X+(0,-.3),SW); [/asy]
 Therefore \[\angle YZX=180^\circ-50^\circ - 70^\circ=\boxed{60^\circ}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes angleA angleB angleC angleYZX :: real
assumes h0 : "angleA = 40"
and h1 : "angleB = 60"
and h2 : "angleC = 80"
and h3 : "angleA + angleB + angleC = 180"
and h4 : "angleYZX = angleB"
shows  "angleYZX = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a triangle, angle A is 40 degrees, angle B is 60 degrees, and angle C is 80 degrees. If the sum of the angles in a triangle is 180 degrees, find the measure of angle YZX, which is equal to angle B. The final answer is 60 degrees.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: "real * real"
and angle :: "real * real * real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> P. P \<in> {X, Y, Z} \<longrightarrow> dist A P + dist B P + dist C P = dist B C + dist A C + dist A B"
and h1 : "dist B X * dist C X = dist B C * dist A X"
and h2 : "dist A Y * dist B Y = dist A B * dist C Y"
and h3 : "dist A Z * dist C Z = dist A C * dist B Z"
and h4 : "angle (A, B, C) = 40"
and h5 : "angle (B, A, C) = 60"
and h6 : "angle (C, A, B) = 80"
shows  "angle (Y, Z, X) = 60"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);
 draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
 label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.
 Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);
 pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,B,X,Y,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,C,Z,X,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Y,Z,A,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]
 size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);
 label("$70^\circ$",Z+(0,.1),NW); label("$70^\circ$",Y+(0,-.2),SW); label("$50^\circ$",X+(0,-.3),SW); [/asy]
 Therefore \[\angle YZX=180^\circ-50^\circ - 70^\circ=\boxed{60^\circ}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: "real * real"
and angle :: "real * real * real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> P. P \<in> {X, Y, Z} \<longrightarrow> dist A P + dist B P + dist C P = dist B C + dist A C + dist A B"
and h1 : "dist B X * dist C X = dist B C * dist A X"
and h2 : "dist A Y * dist B Y = dist A B * dist C Y"
and h3 : "dist A Z * dist C Z = dist A C * dist B Z"
and h4 : "angle (A, B, C) = 40"
and h5 : "angle (B, A, C) = 60"
and h6 : "angle (C, A, B) = 80"
shows  "angle (Y, Z, X) = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In triangle $ABC$, let $X$, $Y$, and $Z$ be points such that for each point $P$ in the set $\{X, Y, Z\}$, the sum of the distances from $P$ to the vertices $A$, $B$, and $C$ is equal to the sum of the side lengths of the triangle, i.e., $AP + BP + CP = AB + BC + AC$. Given that $BX \cdot CX = BC \cdot AX$, $AY \cdot BY = AB \cdot CY$, and $AZ \cdot CZ = AC \cdot BZ$, and that the angles of the triangle are $\angle A = 40^\circ$, $\angle B = 60^\circ$, and $\angle C = 80^\circ$, find the angle $\angle YZX$ in degrees. The final answer is $60^\circ$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: real
assumes h0 : "A = 40"
and h1 : "B = 60"
and h2 : "C = 80"
and h3 : "incircle ABC = circumcircle XYZ"
and h4 : "X \<in> segment BC"
and h5 : "Y \<in> segment AB"
and h6 : "Z \<in> segment AC"
shows  "angle YZX = 60"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);
 draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
 label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.
 Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);
 pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,B,X,Y,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,C,Z,X,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Y,Z,A,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]
 size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);
 label("$70^\circ$",Z+(0,.1),NW); label("$70^\circ$",Y+(0,-.2),SW); label("$50^\circ$",X+(0,-.3),SW); [/asy]
 Therefore \[\angle YZX=180^\circ-50^\circ - 70^\circ=\boxed{60^\circ}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: real
assumes h0 : "A = 40"
and h1 : "B = 60"
and h2 : "C = 80"
and h3 : "incircle ABC = circumcircle XYZ"
and h4 : "X \<in> segment BC"
and h5 : "Y \<in> segment AB"
and h6 : "Z \<in> segment AC"
shows  "angle YZX = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a triangle ABC with angle A = 40 degrees, angle B = 60 degrees, and angle C = 80 degrees, let points X, Y, and Z be on segments BC, AB, and AC, respectively, such that the incircle of triangle ABC coincides with the circumcircle of triangle XYZ. Find the measure of angle YZX. The final answer is 60 degrees.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes angle_A angle_B angle_C angle_YZX :: real
assumes h0 : "angle_A = 40"
and h1 : "angle_B = 60"
and h2 : "angle_C = 80"
and h3 : "angle_A + angle_B + angle_C = 180"
and h4 : "angle_YZX = angle_B"
shows  "angle_YZX = 60"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);
 draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
 label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.
 Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);
 pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,B,X,Y,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,C,Z,X,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Y,Z,A,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]
 size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);
 label("$70^\circ$",Z+(0,.1),NW); label("$70^\circ$",Y+(0,-.2),SW); label("$50^\circ$",X+(0,-.3),SW); [/asy]
 Therefore \[\angle YZX=180^\circ-50^\circ - 70^\circ=\boxed{60^\circ}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes angle_A angle_B angle_C angle_YZX :: real
assumes h0 : "angle_A = 40"
and h1 : "angle_B = 60"
and h2 : "angle_C = 80"
and h3 : "angle_A + angle_B + angle_C = 180"
and h4 : "angle_YZX = angle_B"
shows  "angle_YZX = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a triangle, angle A is 40 degrees, angle B is 60 degrees, and angle C is 80 degrees. If the sum of the three angles is 180 degrees, find the measure of angle YZX, which is equal to angle B. The final answer is 60 degrees.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: real
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 180"
and h1 : "A = 40"
and h2 : "B = 60"
and h3 : "C = 80"
and h4 : "incircle ABC \<longleftrightarrow> circumcircle XYZ"
and h5 : "X \<in> line_segment BC"
and h6 : "Y \<in> line_segment AB"
and h7 : "Z \<in> line_segment AC"
shows  "angle YZX = 60"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);
 draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
 label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.
 Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);
 pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,B,X,Y,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,C,Z,X,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Y,Z,A,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]
 size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);
 label("$70^\circ$",Z+(0,.1),NW); label("$70^\circ$",Y+(0,-.2),SW); label("$50^\circ$",X+(0,-.3),SW); [/asy]
 Therefore \[\angle YZX=180^\circ-50^\circ - 70^\circ=\boxed{60^\circ}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: real
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 180"
and h1 : "A = 40"
and h2 : "B = 60"
and h3 : "C = 80"
and h4 : "incircle ABC \<longleftrightarrow> circumcircle XYZ"
and h5 : "X \<in> line_segment BC"
and h6 : "Y \<in> line_segment AB"
and h7 : "Z \<in> line_segment AC"
shows  "angle YZX = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In triangle $ABC$, $A = 40^\circ$, $B = 60^\circ$, and $C = 80^\circ$. Let $X$, $Y$, and $Z$ be points on the line segments $BC$, $AB$, and $AC$ respectively, such that the incircle of triangle $ABC$ is the circumcircle of triangle $XYZ$. Find the measure of angle $YZX$. The final answer is $60^\circ$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: "real"
assumes h0 : "A = 40"
and h1 : "B = 60"
and h2 : "C = 80"
and h3 : "incircle ABC \<and> circumcircle XYZ"
and h4 : "X \<in> seg BC"
and h5 : "Y \<in> seg AB"
and h6 : "Z \<in> seg AC"
shows  "angle YZX = 60"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);
 draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
 label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.
 Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);
 pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,B,X,Y,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,C,Z,X,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Y,Z,A,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]
 size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);
 label("$70^\circ$",Z+(0,.1),NW); label("$70^\circ$",Y+(0,-.2),SW); label("$50^\circ$",X+(0,-.3),SW); [/asy]
 Therefore \[\angle YZX=180^\circ-50^\circ - 70^\circ=\boxed{60^\circ}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: "real"
assumes h0 : "A = 40"
and h1 : "B = 60"
and h2 : "C = 80"
and h3 : "incircle ABC \<and> circumcircle XYZ"
and h4 : "X \<in> seg BC"
and h5 : "Y \<in> seg AB"
and h6 : "Z \<in> seg AC"
shows  "angle YZX = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In triangle $ABC$, let $A = 40^\circ$, $B = 60^\circ$, and $C = 80^\circ$. Let $X, Y,$ and $Z$ be points on segments $BC$, $AB$, and $AC$ respectively, such that the incircle of triangle $ABC$ and the circumcircle of triangle $XYZ$ are tangent. Find the measure of angle $YZX$. The final answer is $60^\circ$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: "real"
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 180"
and h1 : "A = 40"
and h2 : "B = 60"
and h3 : "C = 80"
and h4 : "angle Y Z X = angle A B C"
shows  "angle Y Z X = 60"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);
 draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
 label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.
 Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);
 pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,B,X,Y,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,C,Z,X,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Y,Z,A,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]
 size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);
 label("$70^\circ$",Z+(0,.1),NW); label("$70^\circ$",Y+(0,-.2),SW); label("$50^\circ$",X+(0,-.3),SW); [/asy]
 Therefore \[\angle YZX=180^\circ-50^\circ - 70^\circ=\boxed{60^\circ}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: "real"
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 180"
and h1 : "A = 40"
and h2 : "B = 60"
and h3 : "C = 80"
and h4 : "angle Y Z X = angle A B C"
shows  "angle Y Z X = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that the sum of angles A, B, and C in a triangle is 180 degrees, with angle A being 40 degrees, angle B being 60 degrees, and angle C being 80 degrees, find the angle YZX if angle YZX is equal to angle ABC. The final answer is 60 degrees.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: "real2" (* real2 represents points in the plane *)
and Γ :: "real2 circle"  (* real2 circle represents a circle in the plane *)
and ∠ :: "real2 ⇒ real2 ⇒ real2 ⇒ real" (* ∠ A B C represents the angle ∠ ABC *)
assumes h0 : "incircle ABC Γ"
and h1 : "circumcircle XYZ Γ"
and h2 : "X ∈ line_segment B C"
and h3 : "Y ∈ line_segment A B"
and h4 : "Z ∈ line_segment A C"
and h5 : "∠ B A C = 40"
and h6 : "∠ A B C = 60"
and h7 : "∠ A C B = 80"
shows  "∠ Y Z X = 60"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $\Gamma$ is the incircle of $\triangle ABC$ and is also the circumcircle of $\triangle XYZ$.  The point $X$ is on $\overline{BC}$, the point $Y$ is on $\overline{AB}$, and the point $Z$ is on $\overline{AC}$.  If $\angle A=40^\circ$, $\angle B=60^\circ$, and $\angle C=80^\circ$, what is the measure of $\angle YZX$? The final Answer is 60^\circ
 ### Proof
 A diagram will probably help. [asy] size(200); pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(unitcircle);
 draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$60^\circ$",B-(0,.2),SW);
 label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); [/asy] Since we are considering the incenter, $AY=AZ$, and likewise around the triangle.
 Therefore the three outer triangles are isosceles. [asy] size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0);
 pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X); label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); markangle(n=1,radius=15,A,Y,Z,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,B,X,Y,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,C,Z,X,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Y,Z,A,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=1),true)));
 markangle(n=1,radius=15,X,Y,B,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=2),true))); markangle(n=1,radius=15,Z,X,C,marker(markinterval(stickframe(n=3),true))); [/asy] This lets us determine two of the angles at $Z$: [asy]
 size(200); import markers; pair X=(1,0); pair Y=dir(120)*(1,0); pair Z=dir(-100)*(1,0); real t =60; pair B=dir(t)*(2.0,0); pair A=dir(t+130)*(2.86,0); pair C=dir(t+250)*(1.6,0); draw(A--B--C--A); draw(X--Y--Z--X);
 label("$A$",A,W); label("$B$",B,NE); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$X$",X,E); label("$Y$",Y,NW); label("$Z$",Z,SW); label("$40^\circ$",A+(.2,.06),E); label("$80^\circ$",C+(0,.15),NW); label("$50^\circ$",Z+(.2,0),NE);
 label("$70^\circ$",Z+(0,.1),NW); label("$70^\circ$",Y+(0,-.2),SW); label("$50^\circ$",X+(0,-.3),SW); [/asy]
 Therefore \[\angle YZX=180^\circ-50^\circ - 70^\circ=\boxed{60^\circ}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X Y Z :: "real2" (* real2 represents points in the plane *)
and Γ :: "real2 circle"  (* real2 circle represents a circle in the plane *)
and ∠ :: "real2 ⇒ real2 ⇒ real2 ⇒ real" (* ∠ A B C represents the angle ∠ ABC *)
assumes h0 : "incircle ABC Γ"
and h1 : "circumcircle XYZ Γ"
and h2 : "X ∈ line_segment B C"
and h3 : "Y ∈ line_segment A B"
and h4 : "Z ∈ line_segment A C"
and h5 : "∠ B A C = 40"
and h6 : "∠ A B C = 60"
and h7 : "∠ A C B = 80"
shows  "∠ Y Z X = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a triangle ABC inscribed in a circle Γ, and points X, Y, Z on the sides BC, AB, AC respectively such that triangle XYZ is circumscribed about Γ. If the angles of triangle ABC are ∠BAC = 40°, ∠ABC = 60°, and ∠ACB = 80°, find the angle ∠YZX. The final answer is 60°.
